marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Primarily letters from N. Atkinson, the overseer of Berkeley's "Goose Pond" plantation, describing in detail crops, marketing of livestock, and weather conditions. There is also an account of tobacco sent to England, 1771, and goods received in return by Robert Beverly; physician's accounts for 1791-1799; and two poems by Edmund Berkeley, one on Pickett's charge.
Kentucky resident (Fayette County) and member of the Army's Quartermaster Department.
A draft signed by a member of the Quartermaster Department, United States Army.
Business correspondence of Carter B. Berkeley, Virginia politician, concerning tobacco shipments and finances, and brief comments on the War of 1812.
Massachusetts resident (Essex County) and Unitarian clergyman.

An undated fragmentary letter ca. 1804 from Benjamin Crowninshield III, a student at the College of William and Mary. Crowninshield discusses the hospitality he has enjoyed in Williamsburg, especially from Bishop James Madison, president of the college. Crowninshield apparently studied with Bentley prior to going to William and Mary.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.

Letter from Thomas Dillon to Major Peter Bennet concerns horses Dillon would like to sell and discusses the horse trading business in North Carolina and adjacent states. Dillon indicates that he would consider trading the horses for a "negro or negroes" whom he would then sell.
Cataloged from card catalog. Formerly cataloged as the Peter Bennet Letter.

Letters from Thomas Benson of Kentucky and Ohio to his mother, sister Catherine, and brother John in Philadelphia in which he discusses family news and his conditions in Ohio and Kentucky. He speaks favorably of emigration to Kentucky. Included is a description of the siege of Fort Meigs on the Maumee River in Ohio during the War of 1812. Thomas Benson was wounded during this siege.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
Virginia resident (Clarke County); wife of George W. Berlin.
Letters chiefly relating to Berlin family matters in Darkesville, Va.; writers include Mary (Van Metre) Tharp of Ohio and George W. Berlin of White Post, Clarke County, Virginia.
Personal correspondence of B.G. Bentley, a merchant in Williamston recently emigrated from Scotland, to Catherine Thompson, a widow in Scotland whom Bentley wished to marry.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
Letter to music critic John Sullivan Dwight, in which Benjamin states that he is publishing Dwight's article on sacred music.
New York City resident and Unitarian clergyman.
Letter from Dexter Clapp commenting on the Unitarian Church in the South.
Personal letters of Horace Benton of Cleveland, Ohio and his cousin, Ira Eddy Benton of Peoria, Illinois, dealing with religious and family matters.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
Resident, Caldwell P.O., Orange Co., N.C.
Personal letters from L.W. Hall to his fiancee, Frances N. Bennett, describing social life, amusements, and religious affairs in Orange County, N.C.
Union Army officer with the 55th Regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry; from Minersville (Schuylkill Co.), Pa.

Civil War diary (94 p.) records the experiences of Lt. Col. Frank T. Bennett as a prisoner of war in Confederate prisons in Charleston and Columbia, S.C., from March 18 to October 10, 1862. There is also an entry about his capture during the Battle of Drewry's Bluff, 1864, and imprisonment in Libby Prison, Richmond, during May 16-October 8 1864.

Bennett speaks well of Southerners in general despite the hardships of prison life, and records his views of Northern military and political tactics. The volume begins with a series of poems and there are a few poems interspersed in the diary entries. A loose item consists of a brief chronoloy of the war and the military service of Frank and of Horace C. Bennett. Horace (d. 1862) may have been Frank's brother.
Editor of the New York Herald newspaper.

Four Civil War letters to Bennett as editor of the New York Herald from reporters L.A. Whiteley and Hiram Calkins in Washington, D.C. In April, 1862, Whiteley reports Union troop movements in Virginia aimed at trapping the Confederates before Richmond as part of the Peninsular campaign. He also reports the source of his information and makes reference to censorship. In a letter dated October 5, 1862, Whiteley reports on rumors surrounding President Lincoln's visit to General McClellan and the possibility of changes in Union army leadership.

Calkin's letter of December 22, 1864, discusses Sherman's activities in Georgia and South Carolina, differences between Commodore David Dixon Porter and General Benjamin F. Butler, and plans for the siege of Richmond. His letter of February 23, 1865, discusses possible plans by Robert E. Lee to move forces below Raleigh, N.C., to stop Sherman's advance north. He also reports various political rumors concerning the presidential election in 1868 and appointments of various cabinet officers.
O.J. Benham, possibly of Tiffin, Ohio, was a soldier in the Fourth Corps of the Army of the Cumberland.

Typescript of diary (19 pages) kept by O.J. Benham, a soldier in the Fourth Corps of the Army of the Cumberland. Diary begins on February 24, 1865 when Benham left Tiffin, Ohio on his way south and ends on June 15, 1865 when Tiffin mustered out and arrived at Cincinnati, Ohio. Diary entries are brief and typically describe his movements, correspondence with his wife, weather, and other routine matters.

Letters written to Bennett from ministers who had served in the Confederate Army in response to his request for material for his book, THE GREAT REVIVAL IN THE SOUTHERN ARMIES. Includes 2 letters from E.M. Bounds of Franklin, Tenn., one from J.A. Parker of Ramer, Ala., and a fragment of a letter from a minister in Pocahontas Co., W. Va. regarding their experiences as ministers to Confederate troops. Letters by Rev. Bounds provide names of many soldiers in the 1st Missouri Brigade as well as accounts of religious activities in camp. The letter by Rev. Parker provides an account of the chaplain's experiences while transporting wounded soldiers across Mobile Bay to hospitals in Mobile, Ala.
Great Revival in the Southern Armies.
Business letters to Benner, in Mulhouse, France, from the Jefferson Insurance Company in Richmond, Va., dealing mostly with company affairs.
Personal letters from Bennett, a resident of Putney, Vermont, to "Dear Uncle," a man perhaps named Baxter.
Cataloged from Guide and card catalog.
"Speculum Vitae: essai de philosophie mystique" manuscripts,
French painter in the symbolism movement.

Collection comprises two versions (1916, 60 pgs.; 1917, 8 pgs.) of Bernard's manuscript entitled "Speculum vitae: essai de philosophie mystique," along with a cover dated 1920. Edits and annotations were made in both manuscripts, and other material or corrections on separate sheets of paper were laid in the 1916 copy, which also includes one illustration.
Alfred and Elizabeth Brand Collection of Rare Books and Manuscripts.
